enriched.title: Rugrats
enriched.synopsis: Focuses on a group of toddlers, most prominently Tommy, Chuckie, Phil, Lil, and Angelica, and their day-to-day lives, usually involving common life experiences that become adventures in the babies' imaginations. While it features frequent slapstick violence, roughhousing, and mild suspense stemming from the babies' misinterpretations of the adult world, the tone is overwhelmingly comedic and focuses on themes of courage, friendship, and problem-solving. It is a Safe viewing option for school-aged children.

enriched.title: The Little Mermaid

It features the adventures of Ariel as a mermaid prior to the events of the film. This series is the first Disney television series to be spun off from a major animated film. enriched.title: Bananas in Pyjamas
enriched.synopsis: Bananas in Pyjamas is an Australian children's television show that premiered on 20 July 1992 on ABC. It has since become syndicated in many different countries, and dubbed into other languages. In the United States, the "Pyjamas" in the title was modified to reflect the American spelling pajamas. This aired in syndication from 1995 to 1997 as a half-hour series, then became a 15-minute show paired with a short-lived 15-minute series The Crayon Box, under a 30-minute block produced by Sachs Family Entertainment titled Bananas in Pajamas & The Crayon Box. Additionally, the characters and a scene from the show were featured in the Kids for Character sequel titled Kids for Character: Choices Count. The pilot episode was Pink Mug.
platforms: Amazon Prime Video Free with Ads

assessment.reasoning: This is a classic, low-stimulation preschool show featuring gentle anthropomorphic characters. Content focuses on basic social skills, sharing, and simple routines, containing no violence or scary imagery. It is highly safe and appropriate for toddlers.

enriched.title: Cracked Ice
enriched.synopsis: It's ice skating time. After a few generic ice-skating gags, we get to the main story. An animal falls through the ice, and a pig doing W.C. Fields (W.C. Squeals, apparently) calls for help from a Saint Bernard dog. The dog dispenses a drink, and Squeals begins scheming to get some himself. First he tries faking his own fall through the ice, but the dog sees through it and downs the drink himself. Then Squeals tries using a dish of bones and a magnet, but the magnet falls through the ice and gets stuck around a fish. The fish then swims through a liquor spill from the dog's casket; the drunken fish grabs an ax and, swimming in a circle, dunks another skater. He then latches onto Squeals' skates, and hauls him into an ice-skating contest, where the fish-induced antics win him first prize. Squeals fills the loving cup from the dog's cask, and the fish swims off with it.

assessment.reasoning: This 1938 cartoon receives a caution rating primarily due to the central theme involving the casual use of alcohol (liquor) for comedic effect, leading to intoxication and chaotic, aggressive behavior (e.g., a drunken fish wielding an ax). The fast-paced slapstick violence and themes of deception make it unsuitable for very young children.

enriched.title: The Brave Engineer
enriched.synopsis: Casey Jones is one of the best engineers there is and it is his duty to get his cargo to its destination on time via train. He sets off but is set back by a number of unfortunate circumstances such as a rain storm, a cow on the tracks, a mad bomber, and finally, when his train starts falling apart. Worst of all, he is on a collision course with another train coming in the opposite direction. After a terrific crash, the man at the train station assumes the worst when Casey doesn't show up but, to his delight, Casey finally makes it to his destination a total wreck but on time (almost).

assessment.reasoning: This short is rated Caution due to its extremely high stimulation level and intense peril, culminating in a 'terrific crash' and the presence of a 'mad bomber.' While the violence is cartoonish, the relentless pace and catastrophic collision may be distressing for children under four.

enriched.title: DC Showcase: Sgt. Rock
enriched.synopsis: Just after recovering from losing his entire unit in battle, Sgt. Rock leads a special army of commandos against a Nazi secret research base.

assessment.reasoning: This PG-13 animated short involves intense war violence, military combat, and frightening sci-fi themes related to a Nazi secret base. The focus on intense action and loss makes the content unsuitable for children under 13.

enriched.title: Captain January
enriched.synopsis: A little girl named Star lives with a lighthouse keeper who rescued her when her parents drowned. A truant officer decides she should go to boarding school but she's rescued by relatives.

assessment.reasoning: This G-rated classic film features no violence or frightening imagery, making it safe for general audiences. The plot includes sad themes of parental drowning and the emotional stress of potential separation from a beloved caregiver, which may be upsetting for very young children. It promotes positive themes of loyalty and family bonds.

enriched.title: DC Showcase: Adam Strange
enriched.synopsis: On a rugged asteroid mining colony, few of the toiling workers are aware that their town drunk was ever anything but an interplanetary derelict. But when the miners open a fissure into the home of a horde of deadly alien insects, his true identity is exposed. He is space adventurer Adam Strange, whose heroic backstory is played out in flashbacks as he struggles to save the very people who have scorned him for so long.

assessment.reasoning: This short carries a PG-13 certification and contains intense sci-fi action violence, including fighting deadly alien insects and high stakes peril. The content is rated 'Unsafe' due to the severity of the action and inclusion of mature themes like alcoholism and dereliction.

enriched.title: Mater and the Ghostlight
enriched.synopsis: Mater, the rusty but trusty tow truck from Cars, spends a day in Radiator Springs playing scary pranks on his fellow townsfolk. That night at Flo's V8 Café, the Sheriff tells the story of the legend of the Ghostlight, and as everyone races home Mater is left alone primed for a good old-fashioned scare.

assessment.reasoning: The short is G-rated, highly comedic, and contains only very mild suspense centered on a folklore scare. The scary element (the Ghostlight legend) is minimal and resolves quickly in a humorous way, making it safe for children over 3. It reinforces positive values regarding friendship and the consequences of pranking others.

enriched.title: Pinocchio's Christmas
enriched.synopsis: As Geppetto prepares for Christmas, Pinocchio joins a puppet show to earn money for a present. There he meets and elopes with the beautiful girl puppet, Julietta, leaving Geppetto alone and worried.

assessment.reasoning: This is a classic Pinocchio story focusing on earning money and familial love during Christmas. While it contains mild cartoon peril and themes of separation when Pinocchio elopes, the content is emotionally resolved and reinforces positive moral values, making it safe for preschoolers and early elementary viewers.

enriched.title: Guillermo del Toro's Pinocchio
enriched.synopsis: During the rise of fascism in Mussolini's Italy, a wooden boy brought magically to life struggles to live up to his father's expectations.

assessment.reasoning: The film is rated Caution due to its handling of mature themes including death, fascism, and war violence. It contains frightening imagery (the afterlife creatures, the sea monster) and complex, emotionally intense scenes better suited for children 10 and older.

enriched.title: Logorama
enriched.synopsis: Two cops portrayed by Michelin Men chase an armed Ronald McDonald through the streets of a fictionalized, stylized city.

assessment.reasoning: This short film contains intense, stylized violence, including armed crime, high-speed car chases, and destruction. The thematic focus on crime and the unsettling apocalyptic ending render the content too intense for children. It is designed for adult viewing and satire.

enriched.title: Fixed
enriched.synopsis: After learning he's getting neutered, a dog has 24 hours to squeeze in one last balls-to-the-wall adventure with the boys.

assessment.reasoning: This film is R-rated and features adult themes, strong sexual references (the plot centers on avoiding neutering), and intense, crude humor. The content is explicitly designed for mature audiences and is highly inappropriate and unsafe for children of any age.

enriched.title: The Pointer
enriched.synopsis: Mickey and Pluto go hunting for quail. Pluto scares away the first ones they see; Mickey scolds him, then relents. He shows Pluto how to be a pointer, and they set off after another quail, but Mickey accidentally jumps on a bear's nose, and thinks it's Pluto. Meanwhile, Pluto finds the quail and points. The babies climb on board and start picking at his hairs, but Pluto's been told not to move. Mickey finally comes across Pluto, who by now is covered by small animals, and realizes he's being followed by a bear. Mickey tries to reason with the bear, and backs off a cliff, onto Pluto.

assessment.reasoning: This classic animated short features mild slapstick violence typical of the era, including aggressive animals and accidental falls (off a cliff). The content is comedic and fast-paced, presenting minimal scary elements and making it appropriate for young children and all ages.
